title: 110_hr7274
content: The Act of 2008 is known as the "Concussion Treatment and Care Tools Act" or the "ConTACT Act". Congress finds that concussions are mild traumatic brain injuries with long-term effects not well understood. Approximately 3.8 million concussions related to sports and recreation occur in the US annually. There is an increased risk of subsequent brain injuries for those with a history of concussions. Repeat concussions can slow recovery or lead to long-term issues, and in rare cases, result in second impact syndrome, causing brain swelling, permanent damage, and death. Recurrent brain injuries and second impact syndrome are preventable. Many national organizations have adopted concussion management guidelines, leading to confusion and debate. SEC. 3. CONCUSSION MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES WITH RESPECT TO STUDENT ATHLETES. Part B of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended by inserting after section 317T the following: "SEC. 317U. CONCUSSION MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES WITH RESPECT TO STUDENT ATHLETES." The Secretary may make grants to States for establishing concussion management guidelines in schools for student athletes, including pre-season baseline testing. States must submit applications to be eligible for grants. States must submit an application for a grant under this section, including an agreement to establish concussion management guidelines for student athletes. Utilization of local chapters of national brain injury organizations is encouraged. A conference on Concussion Management Guidelines must be held within 2 years of the enactment of this section. The Secretary will convene a conference to establish concussion management guidelines for student athletes within 2 years of enactment. Coordination with relevant federal departments is required. A report on the activities and outcomes must be submitted to Congress within 2 years. Implemented computerized pre-season baseline and post-injury neuropsychological testing for student athletes in grades 6th through 12th. Definitions for "State" and "student athlete" are provided. Authorization of $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2009 and additional funding for fiscal years 2010 through 2013 is included.
